org.cast.cwm.components
Class DeployJava

java.lang.Object
  org.apache.wicket.Component
      org.apache.wicket.markup.html.WebComponent
          org.cast.cwm.components.DeployJava
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, org.apache.wicket.IClusterable, org.apache.wicket.IConverterLocator, org.apache.wicket.markup.html.IHeaderContributor
public class DeployJava
extends org.apache.wicket.markup.html.WebComponent
implements org.apache.wicket.markup.html.IHeaderContributor

Wicket component to add the Sun's Deployment Toolkit Javascript. The markup can be defined as any tag that will be replaced by the deployment script. Attributes defined in the tag will be copied to the final applet tag by way of the deployment script.

Note: Sun's Deployment Toolkit does not work with AJAX. If this component is rendered during an ajax call, uses a standard tag instead of Sun's deployment.

Suppose we have the following markup: 

 <div wicket:id="applet" width=200 height=120 code="SignatureApplet.class"
   archive="codesign.jar"></div>
In a Wicket page we can create this component and add it to the page: 
 final DeployJava deployJava = new DeployJava("applet");
 add(deployJava);
We get the following output: 
 <html>
   <head>
     <script type="text/Javascript" src="http://java.com/js/deployJava.js"></script>
   </head>
   <body>
     <script type="text/javascript">
          var attributes = { "width":200,"height":120,"code":"SignatureApplet.class","archive":"codesign.jar", "wicket:id":"applet"};
          var parameters = {};
          var version = null;
          deployJava.runApplet(attributes, parameters, version);
     </script>
     <applet wicket:id="applet" ... >
          ...
     </applet>
   </body>
 </html>

Adapted from Mr. Haki's Post.

See Also:

Constructor Detail

DeployJava

public DeployJava(String id)
Default constructor with markup id.

Parameters:
id - Markup id for applet.

DeployJava

public DeployJava(String id,
                  String jarName,
                  String className)
Constructor that will load a certain jar and class as an applet. Will do its best to search for a jar file beginning with "jarName" in the /WEB-INF/lib folder and add it as a shared resource for this application, if necessary. Usage Example: new DeployJava("appletId", "awesome-applet", "org.example.Applet") The above example will find /WEB-INF/lib/awesome-applet-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar and add it as a shared resource under the DeployJava.class.

Parameters:
id -
jarName -
className -
Method Detail

getSharedArchiveURL

public String getSharedArchiveURL(String jarName)
Provides a URL to a shared resource for the given jarFile. If a resource does not exist, it searches the /WEB-INF/lib folder for a file that starts with the provided name and adds the resource first.

Parameters:
jarName -
Returns:

protected void onComponentTag(org.apache.wicket.markup.ComponentTag tag)
Get the attributes already set and assign them to the attribute list for the Javascript code (or applet tag). And we change the tag name to "script" or "applet" based on whether this is an Ajax call.
